Ok=A0 bear with me(Im a gamer too)...I once found an old atari system with =
like 20 games at a thrift store and remembered back when I was a kid and th=
ought ohhhh yaaaa this was the GREATEST gaming system EVER!!!=A0 So I snagg=
ed it for a whopping 50 bucks...took that bad boy home jimmy rigged it to m=
y new tv system, prepared myself for the awesome graphics of Donkey Kong an=
d Pac-Man....turned it on and went WTF!!!!? WHERES THE AWESOMENESS I REMEMB=
ER, THE COOL GRAPHICS!?!?!?!=A0 
=A0
I think it would be like that...ya it'=
d cool to try it out and relive its glory days for about a week=A0but I'd w=
ant my RS Hack back lol. But it would definately be cool to try and if you =
can afford it and have the paitence to try that method...go for it!=A0 I'd =
love to hear the results. =3D)

people@...> wrote:

Hi Judy. I think i=
f that type of research interests you and you can afford the $160 (and 
any=
thing else you might need to go along with it for EVP purposes), why not? F=
or myself, I 
just find it to be too time consuming and frustrating to go t=
hrough so much recorded 
material for so little in return, content wise, wh=
en we already have the ability (albeit in it's 
infancy) to engage in real-=
time, or nearly real-time, two-way conversations.

Yes, Sarah got amazing r=
esults and bless her pioneering spirit which helped bring us to 
where we a=
re today. I'm not sure how much of her success was her equipment and how 
m=
uch was her energy (I think we are all a component in our sessions). In reg=
ard to 
traditional EVP work, given how good many of today's inexpensive di=
gital recorders are, 
that is the route I've gone for situations where swee=
p isn't an option. I've gotten good EVP 
with my Panasonic RR-US360, the So=
ny B26, and a handful of others. I know some are 
still successfully using =
cassettes. 

I guess it all boils down to a matter of preference and the ty=
pe of EVP research that most 
interests you. As my dear hubby says, "Whatev=
er floats your boat!" ;-)

If you do decide to try Sarah's method, let us k=
now how you do.

Margaret
